summary: This document is an FBI 302 interview summary of a law enforcement officer (referred to as 'IN') who was involved in the burglary investigation at Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence and later the 2005 search warrant execution. The officer details the burglary, Epstein's offer to donate video enhancement technology to the police, and provides observations from the 2005 search, including noting a green massage table with what appeared to be sperm.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the burglary investigation and the subsequent 2005 search warrant for sex crimes. He reported cash stolen and later offered to donate video enhancement technology to the Palm Beach Police Department.

persons.name: Chief
persons.context: The Chief of the Palm Beach Police Department who met with Jeffrey Epstein regarding the donation of video enhancement technology.

connections.description: IN was the investigating officer for the burglary at Epstein's residence and later participated in the 2005 search warrant execution for sex crimes.
Epstein met with the Police Chief to offer a donation of video enhancement technology to the department following the burglary investigation.

events.title: Search of Epstein's Palm Beach Residence
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department executed a search warrant at Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence as part of the sex crimes investigation. Evidence seized included a green massage table with suspected biological material.

events.title: Burglary at Epstein's Palm Beach Residence
events.description: A burglary occurred at Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach home where cash was stolen from a briefcase. Epstein stated he commonly kept large sums of cash ($12,000-$20,000) there.

events.title: Donation of Video Enhancement Technology
events.description: Following the burglary investigation, Jeffrey Epstein offered to buy and donate video enhancement technology (costing $50,000) to the Palm Beach Police Department after being told they lacked such equipment.

locations: Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence (main house, barracks for employees, cabana)
keyFacts: During the 2005 search of Epstein's home, a green massage table was inventoried and an officer recalls seeing what appeared to be sperm on it.
Epstein reported that it was not uncommon for him to keep $12,000 to $20,000 in cash in a briefcase in his home, which was stolen during a burglary.
Epstein donated approximately $50,000 worth of video enhancement technology to the Palm Beach Police Department after the burglary investigation.
The officer (IN) filmed the entire video documentation of the 2005 search warrant execution, which included a protective sweep, reading the warrant, and walk-throughs before and after the search.
The property had three separate structures: the main house, barracks for employees, and a cabana.
